Notes after some work on this -
* we have repos octopress-all (git clone git@codebasehq.com:esolia/rick-cogley/octopress-all.git) and rcop-deploy-1 (git clone git@codebasehq.com:esolia/rick-cogley/rcop-deploy-1.git) located in the rick-cogley project on CodebaseHQ. The former holds everything, is cloned to the author or developer workstation, and is where rake generate and rake deploy are performed to generate and deploy the site.
* local octopress-all is a git repo clone (has a .git/ inside) and inside that is a _deploy folder which is also a git repo, and which is what is pushed to the deploy repo at CodebaseHQ.
* CodebaseHQ can be linked to DeployHQ, and there is a post-commit/push hook set up, that deploys the repo to the server underlying http://rick.cogley.info and http://notes.cogley.info .
* generation and deployment take a while, maybe 10 min altogether, and this is apparently just the way Jekyll works, in that _all_ pages are regenerated and re-deployed via git push to the deploy repo.
* there were some problems with git add, due to differences in line endings from OS to OS, and it appears that we can resolve using git config commands and .gitattributes. It could be that I was causing the changes by opening files with nano.
Some relevant commands -
git config core.autocrlf auto
git config core.autocrlf true
git config core.autocrlf false
Tactically regarding git -
* gitk will open a Wish app (on Mac OS X, at least) that shows the status of the git repo nicely
* when doing git commit -m 'some message' make the message as descriptive as possible
* if there is a conflict make sure to discuss it before resolving, rather than making unilateral changes
* always do git status after an add, to confirm things
Basic workflow -
git clone git@codebasehq.com:esolia/rick-cogley/octopress-all.git //creates the copy of the repo on your local drive
git add . //adds any new files under the folder
git status //lets you check to see what's what
git commit -m 'some detailed message' //tells git what about the files you just added
git push origin master //push the local changes in origin to the master branch in the remote
rake generate //generate site files in public
rake setup_github_pages //sets up the repo you will deploy to, namely git@codebasehq.com:esolia/rick-cogley/rcop-deploy-1.git
rake deploy //copies public to _deploy, then does a git push to the remote deploy repo
git pull origin master //pull changes in the repo from someone else

A couple things about Adobe typekit webfonts -
* it's adobe, so some things about it are fantastic, others odd
* the selection you get is huge
* your typekit subscription is linked to your adobe id
* you create typekit "kits" and edit them with the typekit editor, which you can cause to appear from the typekit site, when you are logged in
* kits have to be set up with domains that you will use with the kit, in kit settings - for example, I put: cogley.info, notes.cogley.info, rick.cogley.info, *.cogley.info, octopress.dev, pashka4281.github.com, localhost, 127.0.0.1
* you add fonts to your kit, then you select sizes. You should choose only the sizes you really are going to use to keep the load size small
* typekit encrypts the fonts, so it appears you cannot grab them out of your browser cache (too bad!)
* when you make a change, like adding or removing a font, or, a size, or changing supported domains, you have to publish the kit, and it takes a few minutes for it to propagate among their servers

update.content:
Ok, this did not work, unfortunately. I was wrong about using the redirect like I did, because for redirects that involve URL parameters, you have to use reWRITEs, according to Webfaction support.
Anyway, I used a regexp to make the change to the .htaccess, and, I put the general /blog /articles redirect statement below the rewrites, because webfaction support said you put the specifics first, then the generals. What they said:
You will need to employ RewriteRules here, as Redirect operates on the URI, not the query string (the characters after the question mark, i.e. id=8835418616432697593):
RewriteEngine On
RewriteCond %{REQUEST_URI} ^/blog/index.php$
RewriteCond %{QUERY_STRING} ^id=8835418616432697593$
RewriteRule ^(.*)$ http://notes.cogley.info/articles/2012/12/24/assign-elastic-ip-fixed-public-ip-to-your-amazon-ec2 [R=301,L]
Please test and report problems back here.
The regexp I used attached in a screenshot. (This gskinner.com tool is available for linux too)
I made sure it worked by testing one set to notes.cogley.info, and once I confirmed that, I switched it back to rick.cogley.info, which won't work again until we switch to live.

There was one problem, which was that redirecting /blog to /articles also had impact on subfolders like /blog/archives.
The key to fixing was, to add a:
RedirectMatch 301 ^/blog$ /articles
... to specify that only /blog/ and not its children should be forwarded.
The basics are now working well so I will close this. After this it's checking google webmaster tools for problems and tweaking the file.
One last thing - webfaction mentioned another possibility -
> Hello,
>
> Redirect rules cascade, so this should be technically possible with a
> 'not' ! symbol. Something like this should do it,
>
> RewriteEngine On RewriteCond %{REQUEST_URI} !^/blog/archives/$
> RewriteCond %{REQUEST_URI} ^/blog/index.php$ RewriteCond
> %{QUERY_STRING} ^id=8835418616432697593$ RewriteRule ^(.*)$
> http://notes.cogley.info/articles/2012/12/24/assign-elastic-ip-fixed-public-ip-to-your-amazon-ec2
> [R=301,L]
>
> The exclamation ! means 'not'. The code above basically is saying, 'if
> the URI is not this, but is that than do whatever'
>
> Please let us know if you have any questions.
>
> John S. WebFaction Support
